content: The Act may be cited as the "Torture Survivors Support Act". The American people abhor torture as it creates fear and insecurity. Torture is deliberate mental and physical damage by governments to individuals, with long-term effects. Repressive governments use torture to eliminate opposition and terrorize society. Torture survivors face ongoing threats, especially when perpetrators are not held accountable. Many refugees and asylees in the United States have been victims of torture and deserve prompt consideration for political asylum. Torture survivors living in the US should receive rehabilitation services to become productive community members. The development of a treatment movement for torture survivors is crucial. The development of a treatment movement for torture survivors has created new opportunities for action by the United States and other nations to oppose state-sponsored torture. A comprehensive strategy is needed to protect and support torture victims and their treatment providers, along with efforts to eliminate torture globally. The United States can help heal the effects of torture and prevent its use worldwide by supporting survivors and their families. SEC. 3. DEFINITIONS. UNITED STATES POLICY WITH RESPECT TO THE INVOLUNTARY RETURN OF PERSONS IN DANGER OF SUBJECTION TO TORTURE. The United States policy prohibits the involuntary return of individuals to countries where they may face torture. Aliens who claim to have been tortured or are believed to have been tortured are covered under this section. When considering their application for refugee status, asylum, or withholding of removal, officials must consider how torture may affect the applicant's responses and their difficulties in recounting their suffering. Victims' fear of returning to their country is also taken into account. Refugees who have been subjected to torture are considered of special humanitarian concern and are given priority for resettlement in the United States. Special procedures are in place for aliens who are victims of torture when applying for refugee status, asylum, or withholding of removal. Refugees subjected to torture are given priority for resettlement in the US. Expedited procedures are in place for aliens claiming torture, speeding up asylum interviews or removal proceedings. Refugees claiming torture are prioritized for resettlement in the US, with expedited procedures for asylum interviews or removal proceedings if torture is alleged. Postponement of proceedings is allowed if mental or physical symptoms from torture are evident. The Survivors of Torture Support Act prioritizes refugees claiming torture for resettlement in the US and allows for parole instead of detention based on the alien's condition. It is recommended that the Attorney General allocate resources to maintain current information on torture in foreign countries. SEC. 6. SPECIALIZED TRAINING FOR CONSULAR, IMMIGRATION, AND ASYLUM PERSONNEL. The Attorney General and the Secretary of State provide specialized training for immigration and consular officials on identifying torture, its effects on victims, and how to conduct interviews with victims sensitively. Gender-specific training on interacting with male and female victims of torture by rape or sexual violence is required during specialized training for immigration and consular officials.
